content: @pnkfelix I feel like this ended up being forgotten. That said, I don't believe RLS is being actively worked on anymore and everybody uses rust-analyzer nowadays? Is my intuition wrong?
My impression is that most new (and old) users pick RLS because there's no mention of rust-analyzer on the language website.
What's the status of that transition RFC?
I think we're still only shipping RA as a preview on nightly
(in rustup)

RFC is accepted, vscode-rust has an older version of the integration that's currently broken, and the rustup version is reasonably up-to-date these days (less than a week old, depending on the bors queue). matklad said he was trying to find a way to move forward on this.

matklad said:

Oh, one more thing from me -- no progress on "rust-anlyzer is a part of rust-lang/rust organizaion" , guess I'll do another round of pings

This is the last we've heard in that regard so far I think

Anecdote: On the Community Discord essentially no one uses RLS, and if people say they've got a problem with RLS they're usually told that they should just switch to RA because that's what's being worked on.

Laurențiu said:

My impression is that most new (and old) users pick RLS because there's no mention of rust-analyzer on the language website.

Another anecdote: my brother just started learning rust yesterday and asked me whether he should use RLS or rust-analyzer. And I'd assume anyone asking gets told rust-analyzer, so there's probably more people picking it up first than you think
Yeah, but you've reported issues to rust-analyzer. That's pretty uncommon. And I see a lot of new users posting on old RLS issues.
I guess that's something the Rust Survey can help figure out.

Laurențiu said:

Yeah, but you've reported issues to rust-analyzer. That's pretty uncommon. And I see a lot of new users posting on old RLS issues.

oh sure, I know I'm the odd man out - my point was that even new users are asking which they should use (so they're not using RLS by default)
https://blog.rust-lang.org/2020/12/16/rust-survey-2020.html doesn't say much on the topic, while https://blog.rust-lang.org/2020/04/17/Rust-survey-2019.html had RLS at 43% and RA at 15%

We didn't report this in the blog post, but here are the raw numbers from the 2020 survey:
image.png
So rust-analyzer is definitely dominate
We will definitely be asking this again

Laurențiu said:

My impression is that most new (and old) users pick RLS because there's no mention of rust-analyzer on the language website.

This still bites people: https://github.com/rust-lang/vscode-rust/issues/927. joaomoreno from GitHub implemented a whole new feature for rust-lang.rust and submitted a PR before commenting there.

Would it make sense for the vscode plugin to change the default tool installed and switch to rust-analyzer?
(not sure about what this implies in terms of testing the plugin installation)

If the reality is that everyone uses rust-analyzer, probably the Dev tools team should update the plugin repository and write an official statement about RLS 1.0

I'm not sure that's a good idea. There is a non-trivial amount of client-side code and it's not that easy to switch the implementations and keep this working, not to mention the massive amount of confusion it might cause -- TBH, I think any branding change will lead to confusion, with users reading on the Internet that they shouldn't use RLS.

I think renaming the old extension might be a better approach. Existing users won't find the rug being pulled from under themselves, while new ones.. they'll pick whatever they see on the website, or are told on Discord.
